comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You can see this landing stage on the OS 25" map, but I don't remember it, so it must have been removed not too long after this photo. This page (by Irish Ship and Barge Fabrication) states that the last barge sailed in 1961.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Here's a video of the same barge "on the move" - with funnels reclined. (Niall has the photo location spot-on BTW)

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: What a great old picture NLI, I love it and thank you for sharing.  keep up the good work, your pictures are appreciated.

comment.author: 69751036@N08
comment._content: Where did they store the barrels.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: If you watch [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] 's video, you can see the barge full of empties going upstream.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Lovely to see the landing stage on the OSI Historic Map! And interesting that we kept the name Victoria Quay, but on the other side of the river, the Quay named for her Consort, Albert, has been changed to Wolfe Tone Quay.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Thanks a million for the video! Very cute the way the funnel could fold down going under low bridges, though not impressed with the barrels. Would have thought they'd be stacked far more neatly.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] No problem at all! Hope the people in your Group enjoy it too.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Fantastic article, Old Pete! Really enjoyed the accounts of the barges during the Civil War and the "Emergency".
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 61286047@N00
comment._content:
Reminds me of Ulysses, though this is not Prince's Street of course:

"Grossbooted draymen rolled barrels dullthudding out of Prince's
stores and bumped them up on the brewery float. On the brewery float
bumped dullthudding barrels rolled by grossbooted draymen out of
Prince's stores. "

comment.author: 60329026@N07
comment._content: A street view from the north quays shows the Harbor Masters Office (still there today), where the Guinness Barges took on their loads from the brewery The Dockside was removed I think in the early sixties. If you look closely from the north quay you can make out the newer stonework when the Barge moorings were removed. Link maps.google.com/maps/ms?ie=UTF8&oe=UTF8&msa=0&...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In this Streetview, you can see where the tramway came out out of the archway to the left from the brewery, and the newer stonework on the right where the tramway went out onto the landing stage. Paler stone blocks in the river wall can be seen here, where the tramway crossed again, but the brewery wall has been changed since then, and there is no sign of the old gate here.
